P087152.project_name: Mexico Savings & Rural Finance (BANSEFI) Project - Phase II

keywords.cdata: access to financial services, accounting, actual cost, ADDITIONAL FINANCING, additional income, advisory services, agriculture bank, alternative credit, ATMs, auditing, auditors, bailout, bank account, bank branch, Bank financing, Bank funding, Bank Loan, banking products, banking sector, Borrower, branch location, branch network, bullet repayment, Capacity Building, cash flows, checks, collateral, commercial banks, competition policy, Consolidation, consolidation process, cooperatives, cost recovery, credibility, credit cards, credit history, Credit Institutions, Credit Law, credit unions, CURRENCY, debit card, deposit, deposit insurance, Deposit Protection, depositor, depositors, deposits, development banking, development banks, Disbursement, earnings, Economic Analysis, economic empowerment, economic shocks, electronic banking, entrepreneurs, Exchange Rate, expenditures, farm income, finance cost, finance costs, financial analyses, financial analysis, financial assets, financial benefits, financial intermediaries, Financial Management, Financial Management Arrangements, financial performance, financial products, financial reporting, financial sector development, Financial Services, financial sustainability, financial viability, fiscal management, Flexible Loan, foreign exchange, foreign exchange transactions, formal financial markets, formal financial sector, formal financial services, government aid, government investment, government subsidies, Grace Period, high interest

project_abstract.cdata: The project development objective of the Savings & Rural Finance Second Phase Project for Mexico is to assist the Borrower in strengthening the savings and credit institutions sector with institutions which are compliant with the popular savings and credit law, and are financially viable, operationally effective, managerially sound, technologically upgraded, and providing an enhanced level of outreach and access to financial services by the underserved Mexican populations. The additional loan will meet the financing gap relating to existing project activities. The Phase II Project experienced a cost overrun, predominantly in the technology platform refining and scaling-up component. Since this is Mexico's home-grown solution to the information technology needs of the rural financial sector, it has had to address many undefined "firsts". This additional loan finances this cost escalation.
